category_summary:
A landmark day dominated by **Anthropic's** [$30B raise](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-c7aced803a36) at a $380B valuation and simultaneous reveal of [$14B run-rate revenue](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-aa4cfef9fbee) with 10x annual growth. An **Anthropic** engineer attributed much of the fundraise momentum to [**Claude Code**](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-8a182bfac352), whose weekly active users doubled since January.

- **Sam Altman** [launched **GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark**](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-b374f120dd88) as a research preview, touting 1000+ tokens/sec via a new **Cerebras** hardware partnership
- **Demis Hassabis** and **Noam Shazeer** announced a major [**Gemini 3 Deep Think** upgrade](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-d56a25f6fd30) achieving SOTA on ARC-AGI-2 (84.6%), 3455 Codeforces Elo, and gold-medal Physics/Chemistry Olympiad performance ‚Äî independently certified by **Fran√ßois Chollet**
- **Google** also unveiled **Aletheia**, a math research agent powered by Deep Think that solved multiple open **Erd≈ës** problems

On the ideas front, **John Carmack** [argued AI will shift economic value](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-ed513961e086) from raw intelligence to agency, empowering a new class of high-agency individuals. **Andrej Karpathy** highlighted [**Simile AI's** novel approach](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-9db35d5d5745) of using LLMs as population simulators rather than single-personality chatbots. **Chollet** [provided a definitive historical account](/?date=2026-02-13&category=social#item-95bca28ce670) of the ARC benchmarks, pushing back on narratives that they were designed as anti-LLM tests.

items.title: The modern age has richly rewarded people with a combination of high intelligence and high agency. N...
items.content:
The modern age has richly rewarded people with a combination of high intelligence and high agency. Now that many aspects of intelligence are successfully being automated, it seems likely that people with relatively lower intelligence but exceptional agency will come into their own if they are willing to egolessly accept AI advice.

Imagine a ruthless criminal that completely trusts everything their always-on AI glasses are telling them, knowing that it is carefully looking out for their best interests and isn‚Äôt scheming to betray them.

items.title: Lots of folks spread false narratives about how ARC-1 was created in response to LLMs, or how ARC-2 ...
items.content:
Lots of folks spread false narratives about how ARC-1 was created in response to LLMs, or how ARC-2 was only created because ARC-1 was saturated. Setting the record straight:

1. ARC-1 was designed 2017-2019 and released in 2019 (pre LLMs).

2. The coming of ARC-2 was announced in May 2022 (pre ChatGPT).

3. By mid-2024, there was still essentially no progress on ARC-1.

4. All progress on ARC-1 & ARC-2 came from a new paradigm, test-time adaptation models, starting in late 2024 and ramping up through 2025.

5. Progress happened specifically *because* research moved away from what ARC was intended to challenge (static DL), toward what ARC was intended to encourage (test-time adaptation). ARC was meant to steer AI research towards fluid intelligence, and it is only by implementing fluid intelligence that it could be solved.

6. To this day, base LLMs (no test-time adaptation) *still* perform abysmally low on ARC despite a 50,000x scaleup since 2020, which confirms what we predicted about this paradigm not being capable of fluid intelligence and therefore not being capable of solving ARC.

7. ARC-3 was announced in February 2025, back when ARC-2 was completely unsaturated. ARC-3 is not in response to ARC-2 getting saturated.

8. We never claimed solving ARC would be proof of having achieved AGI; all the way back to 2021-2022 and every single year since we made it very explicit that it would NOT be proof of AGI. ARC is a research tool that was intended to steer AI research towards fluid intelligence, which it did.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet provides comprehensive history of ARC benchmarks: designed 2017-2019, progress came from test-time adaptation (not LLM scaling), base LLMs still perform poorly, ARC never claimed to prove AGI. Details ARC-3 through ARC-7 roadmap.
items.reasoning: Definitive historical record from ARC creator. Very high engagement (986 likes, 50K views). Important correction of multiple false narratives. Clarifies the paradigm shift from static DL to test-time adaptation.

items.title: Reaching AGI won't be beating a benchmark. It will be the end of the human-AI gap. Benchmarks are si...
items.content:
Reaching AGI won't be beating a benchmark. It will be the end of the human-AI gap. Benchmarks are simply a way to estimate the current gap, which is why we need to continually release new benchmarks (focused on the remaining gap). Benchmarking is a process, not a fixed point.

We can say we have AGI when it's no longer possible to come up with a test that evidences the gap. When it's no longer possible to point to something that regular humans can do and AI can't.

Today, it's still easy. I expect it will become nearly impossible by 2030.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet defines AGI as the end of the human-AI gap, argues benchmarks are a process not a fixed point, and expects the gap to close by ~2030.
items.reasoning: Major thought leadership from ARC creator on AGI definition and timeline. High engagement (710 likes, 33K views). Original framework for thinking about AGI measurement.

items.title:
Congrats on the launch @simile_ai ! (and I am excited to be involved as a small angel.)

Simile is w...
items.content:
Congrats on the launch @simile_ai ! (and I am excited to be involved as a small angel.)

Simile is working on a really interesting, imo under-explored dimension of LLMs. Usually, the LLMs you talk to have a single, specific, crafted personality. But in principle, the native, primordial form of a pretrained LLM is that it is a simulation engine trained over the text of a highly diverse population of people on the internet. Why not lean into that statistical power: Why simulate one "person" when you could try to simulate a population? How do you build such a simulator? How do you manage its entropy? How faithful is it? How can it be useful? What emergent properties might arise of similes in loops?

Imo these are very interesting, promising and under-explored topics and the team here is great. All the best!

items.summary: Karpathy announces his angel investment in Simile AI, which explores using LLMs as population simulators rather than single-personality chatbots ‚Äî simulating diverse populations from pretraining data.
items.reasoning: Major thought leadership from Karpathy on novel LLM paradigm. Extremely high engagement (5378 likes, 534K views). Original framing of LLMs as population simulation engines. Also announces a startup.

items.title: We‚Äôve upgraded our specialized reasoning mode Gemini 3 Deep Think to help solve modern science, rese...

items.title:
Yesterday I tried to vibe code a refactor of an ML library into a new more efficient framework. 

I ...
items.content:
Yesterday I tried to vibe code a refactor of an ML library into a new more efficient framework. 

I followed some of the "best practices" I heard of here: created the refactor plan with Claude and then implemented it in Codex.

It was a disaster. No meaningful speedup for any of the algos.

Then I told Codex to ignore all the previous work and reimplement everything from scratch using its own best judgement. 

I woke up this morning to massive speedups. 

Still need to verify it all, but so far it looks extremely promising.

items.reasoning: Highly valuable first-hand account of AI-assisted coding workflow for ML. Key insight: over-planning with one AI then implementing with another failed, but giving Codex full autonomy succeeded. 326 likes, 35K views. Practical lesson for AI-assisted development. Challenges conventional 'best practices' for vibe coding.

I followed some of the "best practices" I heard of here: created the refactor plan with Claude and then implemented it in Codex.

I woke up this morning to massive speedups.

Still need to verify it all, but so far it looks extremely promising.

items.title: A good canary in the coal mine for AI-caused job loss will be call centers. We're currently projecti...
items.content:
A good canary in the coal mine for AI-caused job loss will be call centers. We're currently projecting ~2.75M call center jobs in the US in 2026. In 2016 it was ~2.63M. The global call center market size has grown ~35% in that time period (from $298B to $405B). Peak employment was 2019 at ~2.98M.

When we see a -50% employment drop in this sector you can get ready for broad disruption across the economy.

The latest Deep Think moves beyond abstract theory to drive practical applications.

It‚Äôs state-of-the-art on ARC-AGI-2, a benchmark for frontier AI reasoning.

On Humanity‚Äôs Last Exam, it sets a new standard, tackling the hardest problems across mathematics, science, and engineering ‚Äî making it a genuine collaborator for heavy-duty analysis.

It achieved an Elo of 3455 on Codeforces, demonstrating the ability to solve complex, real-world coding tasks - while earning gold medal-level results on the written portion of the 2025 Physics and Chemistry Olympiads.

items.title: Over 50 million views for that @MattShumer_ blog (‚ÄúSomething Big is Happening‚Äù) and not a shred of a...
items.content:
Over 50 million views for that @MattShumer_ blog (‚ÄúSomething Big is Happening‚Äù) and not a shred of actual data. 

Nobody thought to ask what are the data? Does this match reality? Is Shumer credible? Did he give a single concrete example? 

People gonna believe what they want to believe, but here are 7 critical points most people missed:

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer‚Äôs blog post is weaponized hype, filled with vivid narrative and marketing speech, but stumbles on the facts, especially with respect to reliability. He gives no actual data to support this claim that the latest coding systems can (reliably) write ‚Äúperfect‚Äù whole complex apps without making errors.  

‚Ä¢¬†When he describes how AI‚Äôs are doing longer and longer tasks on METR‚Äôs famous task-time benchmark, he neglects to say the criterion on that benchmark is 50% correct, not 100%, and that the benchmark is only about coding and not tasks in general. No AI system can reliably do every five-hour long task humans can do without error, or even close. But you wouldn‚Äôt know that reading Shumer‚Äôs blog, which largely ignores all the hallucination and boneheaded errors that are so common in every day experience. 

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer didn‚Äôt cite the new Caltech/Stanford article that reviews a wide range of reasoning errors in so-called reasoning models [or the Apple reasoning paper or the ASU mirage paper, etc]. The picture he sells just isn‚Äôt realistic, however much people might wish it were true. 

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer is the guy who was once famous for apparently exaggerated claims about a big model of his that didn‚Äôt replicate and that many people saw as fraud; he likes to sell big. But that doesn‚Äôt mean we should take him seriously.

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer made no reference to a different METR study showed that coders sometimes imagine big productivity gains where they actually lost productivity. (Even though he selectively mentioned their other well-known study).

‚Ä¢ He also didn‚Äôt acknowledge that other user‚Äôs experience is certainly not ‚Äúit‚Äôs usually perfect.‚Äù @KelseyTuocreported a few weeks back that Claude Code was sometimes perfect, and other times maddening. (Example: ‚ÄúSometimes, Claude is absolutely the worst coworker you‚Äôve ever had. At one point, it deleted every single one of the phoneme files of each English sound pronounced [that she was working with in her app] absolutely correctly, which I had personally emailed an English teacher to secure permission to use, and replaced them with AI-generated sounds which were all subtly wrong.‚Äù) Shumer glosses over that kind of experience. ‚Ä®Ôøº
‚Ä¢LLMs write code wicked fast, but some coders are starting to report burnout, and only relatively modest gains relative to that burnout, as a new story from Connie Loizos at Tech Crunch just reported.

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer is actually correct that something has changed recently. You really can let things rip more in the most recent systems. Bit, quoting from a developer friend ‚Äúsometimes!  [it] will come out with the right answer. ‚Ä¶ Sometimes‚Ä¶ [But] ultimately, I think this makes it more dangerous ‚Ä¶. Generally, the closer these systems are to appearing right, the more dangerous they become‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Ä¢ The security of the autogenerated code is very much in question. 

The bottom line is this: LLMs are certainly coding more, but it‚Äôs not clear that the code they are creating is secure or trustworthy. Shumer‚Äôs presentation is completely one-sided, omitting lots of concerns that have been widely expressed here and elsewhere. 

A lot of people may have taken his post seriously, but they shouldn‚Äôt have.

Adapted from my newsletter, Marcus on AI (nearly 100k subscribers).

items.content_html:
Over 50 million views for that @MattShumer_ blog (‚ÄúSomething Big is Happening‚Äù) and not a shred of actual data.

Nobody thought to ask what are the data? Does this match reality? Is Shumer credible? Did he give a single concrete example?

People gonna believe what they want to believe, but here are 7 critical points most people missed:

‚Ä¢ Shumer‚Äôs blog post is weaponized hype, filled with vivid narrative and marketing speech, but stumbles on the facts, especially with respect to reliability. He gives no actual data to support this claim that the latest coding systems can (reliably) write ‚Äúperfect‚Äù whole complex apps without making errors.

‚Ä¢ When he describes how AI‚Äôs are doing longer and longer tasks on METR‚Äôs famous task-time benchmark, he neglects to say the criterion on that benchmark is 50% correct, not 100%, and that the benchmark is only about coding and not tasks in general. No AI system can reliably do every five-hour long task humans can do without error, or even close. But you wouldn‚Äôt know that reading Shumer‚Äôs blog, which largely ignores all the hallucination and boneheaded errors that are so common in every day experience.

‚Ä¢ Shumer didn‚Äôt cite the new Caltech/Stanford article that reviews a wide range of reasoning errors in so-called reasoning models [or the Apple reasoning paper or the ASU mirage paper, etc]. The picture he sells just isn‚Äôt realistic, however much people might wish it were true.

‚Ä¢ Shumer is the guy who was once famous for apparently exaggerated claims about a big model of his that didn‚Äôt replicate and that many people saw as fraud; he likes to sell big. But that doesn‚Äôt mean we should take him seriously.

‚Ä¢ Shumer made no reference to a different METR study showed that coders sometimes imagine big productivity gains where they actually lost productivity. (Even though he selectively mentioned their other well-known study).

‚Ä¢ He also didn‚Äôt acknowledge that other user‚Äôs experience is certainly not ‚Äúit‚Äôs usually perfect.‚Äù @KelseyTuocreported a few weeks back that Claude Code was sometimes perfect, and other times maddening. (Example: ‚ÄúSometimes, Claude is absolutely the worst coworker you‚Äôve ever had. At one point, it deleted every single one of the phoneme files of each English sound pronounced [that she was working with in her app] absolutely correctly, which I had personally emailed an English teacher to secure permission to use, and replaced them with AI-generated sounds which were all subtly wrong.‚Äù) Shumer glosses over that kind of experience. ‚Ä®Ôøº

‚Ä¢LLMs write code wicked fast, but some coders are starting to report burnout, and only relatively modest gains relative to that burnout, as a new story from Connie Loizos at Tech Crunch just reported.

‚Ä¢ Shumer is actually correct that something has changed recently. You really can let things rip more in the most recent systems. Bit, quoting from a developer friend ‚Äúsometimes! [it] will come out with the right answer. ‚Ä¶ Sometimes‚Ä¶ [But] ultimately, I think this makes it more dangerous ‚Ä¶. Generally, the closer these systems are to appearing right, the more dangerous they become‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Ä¢ The security of the autogenerated code is very much in question.

The bottom line is this: LLMs are certainly coding more, but it‚Äôs not clear that the code they are creating is secure or trustworthy. Shumer‚Äôs presentation is completely one-sided, omitting lots of concerns that have been widely expressed here and elsewhere.

A lot of people may have taken his post seriously, but they shouldn‚Äôt have.

Adapted from my newsletter, Marcus on AI (nearly 100k subscribers).

items.title:
@kevinroose None of what you just said is remotely accurate.

ARC did not come out 2 years ago but o...
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet corrects Kevin Roose: ARC was created 6+ years ago (not 2), ARC-2 was announced before ARC-1 was saturated, and ARC was never said to be impossible ‚Äî just impossible for LLMs, which proved correct since progress came from test-time adaptation.
items.reasoning: Important factual correction from benchmark creator. Very high engagement (1032 likes, 37K views). Clarifies key technical distinction between LLMs and test-time adaptation.
items.summary_html: Chollet corrects Kevin Roose: ARC was created 6+ years ago (not 2), ARC-2 was announced before ARC-1 was saturated, and ARC was never said to be impossible ‚Äî just impossible for LLMs, which proved correct since progress came from test-time adaptation.
items.content_html:
@kevinroose None of what you just said is remotely accurate.

ARC did not come out 2 years ago but over 6 years ago. ARC-2 was announced several years before ARC-1 was saturated.

And ARC was never said to be impossible for AI (the point of the benchmark was obviously to get solve by AI). It was said to be impossible for LLMs, which proved accurate. Progress came from pivoting towards test-time adaption, not from scaling up LLMs. *To this very day* base LLMs still perform abysmally low on ARC.

items.title: Gemini 3 Deep Think is getting an upgrade üß† By blending deep scientific knowledge with advanced engi...
items.content:
Gemini 3 Deep Think is getting an upgrade üß† By blending deep scientific knowledge with advanced engineering utility, Deep Think now moves beyond abstract theory to drive practical applications.

Researchers are already using it to accelerate their work in the real world:

‚Äî Materials science: A university lab used Deep Think to optimize the growth of complex crystals that are candidates for high-temperature semiconductors 
‚Äî Mechanical engineering: A researcher demonstrated how Deep Think can be used to iterate on physical prototypes at the speed of software. When applied to things like assistive devices, this pace means faster improvements for life-changing technology (more information on this use case in the video below!)

The updated Deep Think is available in @GeminiApp  for Google AI Ultra subscribers.

items.content:
We don‚Äôt have any barriers to bots flooding every online space. They can use browsers and make payments. In fact, it is arguably a better deal to pay for a bot to access a social media site, since it can post and carry out your agenda when you sleep.

Online spaces are about to get (even more) grim.

I generally don't expect to see AI-caused mass unemployment in the next 5 years.

items.title: Existing AI agents are largely short-horizon (e.g. chat) or constrained (e.g. agentic process automa...
items.content:
Existing AI agents are largely short-horizon (e.g. chat) or constrained (e.g. agentic process automation). @sequoia predicted that 2026 is the year of long-horizon agents, and long-horizon agents ~= AGI

We‚Äôre already seeing this with coding agents. But I‚Äôm specifically excited about how this translates to non-technical knowledge work over documents (e.g. legal, finance, insurance, back office) that humans typically perform for hours on end.

I wrote a blog post that articulates the broader class of use cases this would unlock, and the ideal architecture/UX of an ‚Äúagent inbox‚Äù that allows agents to run autonomously without being blocked on human input. Unlike a chat interface.

Some examples:
1. An agent that can continuously create a living FAQ from your Sharepoint, Slack, call transcripts
2. An agent that can e2e interface with lawyers to do contract redlining

This fundamentally requires building agents that can monitor event triggers beyond human chat inputs, and can use core capabilities around parsing, extracting, creating, and editing documents of various formats.

Check out the blog! https://t.co/czzs3ZDs8g
If you‚Äôre interested in the building blocks around parsing, extraction, with more coming soon, come check out LlamaCloud: https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) writing about 2026 being the year of long-horizon AI agents, describing agent inbox architecture for autonomous workflows in legal, finance, insurance. References Sequoia prediction that long-horizon agents ‚âà AGI.
items.reasoning: Thoughtful analysis from LlamaIndex founder on the evolution from chat-based to long-horizon autonomous agents, with concrete use cases and architectural ideas. Relevant industry thought leadership.
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) writing about 2026 being the year of long-horizon AI agents, describing agent inbox architecture for autonomous workflows in legal, finance, insurance. References Sequoia prediction that long-horizon agents ‚âà AGI.

We‚Äôre already seeing this with coding agents. But I‚Äôm specifically excited about how this translates to non-technical knowledge work over documents (e.g. legal, finance, insurance, back office) that humans typically perform for hours on end.

I wrote a blog post that articulates the broader class of use cases this would unlock, and the ideal architecture/UX of an ‚Äúagent inbox‚Äù that allows agents to run autonomously without being blocked on human input. Unlike a chat interface.

Some examples:

1. An agent that can continuously create a living FAQ from your Sharepoint, Slack, call transcripts

items.title: I spent more test time compute and realized that my micrograd can be dramatically simplified even fu...
items.content:
I spent more test time compute and realized that my micrograd can be dramatically simplified even further. You just return local gradients for each op and get backward() to do the multiply (chaining) with global gradient from loss. So each op just expresses the bare fundamentals of what it needs to: the forward computation and the backward gradients for it.

Huge savings from 243 lines of code to just 200 (~18%).

Also, the code now fits even more beautifully to 3 columns and happens to break just right:

Column 1: Dataset, Tokenizer, Autograd
Column 2: GPT model
Column 3: Training, Inference

Ok now surely we are done.

items.summary: Karpathy explains simplifying micrograd by returning local gradients and letting backward() do the chaining, reducing from 243 to 200 lines. Code fits 3 columns: Dataset/Tokenizer/Autograd, GPT model, Training/Inference.

items.title: New course: A2A: The Agent2Agent Protocol, built with  @googlecloudtech and @IBMResearch, and taught...
items.content:
New course: A2A: The Agent2Agent Protocol, built with  @googlecloudtech and @IBMResearch, and taught by Holt Skinner, @ivnardini, and Sandi Besen.

Connecting agents built with different frameworks usually requires extensive custom integration. This short course teaches you A2A, the open protocol standardizing how agents discover each other and communicate. Since IBM‚Äôs ACP (Agent Communication Protocol) joined forces with A2A, A2A has emerged as the industry standard.

In this course, you'll build a healthcare multi-agent system where agents built with different frameworks, such as Google ADK (Agent Development Kit) and LangGraph, collaborate through A2A. You'll wrap each agent as an A2A server, build A2A clients to connect to them, and orchestrate them into sequential and hierarchical workflows.

Skills you'll gain:
- Expose agents from different frameworks as A2A servers to make them discoverable and interoperable
- Chain A2A agents sequentially using ADK, where one agent's output feeds into the next
- Connect A2A agents to external data sources using MCP (Model Context Protocol)
- Deploy A2A agents using Agent Stack, IBM's open-source infrastructure

Join and learn the protocol standardizing agent collaboration! 
https://t.co/5EDqpuvd0z

items.title:
These benchmarks üòû This is how you break them:

1. Ask your most capable model to read a public task...
items.content:
These benchmarks üòû This is how you break them:

1. Ask your most capable model to read a public task A and generate a similar task and then solve it. Given that the solution is verifiable, you get a collection of task-solutions similar to public task A but not copying it.

2. Then you do the same for public task B, etc.

3. Once you have this collection of synthetic tasks, you finetune your most capable model to solve these tasks so it becomes better. Better for this benchmark and nothing else.

Rinse. Repeat.

2. Then you do the same for public task B, etc.

3. Once you have this collection of synthetic tasks, you finetune your most capable model to solve these tasks so it becomes better. Better for this benchmark and nothing else.

Rinse. Repeat.

items.title: No, I don't think that AI will destroy *all* SaaS. Most people don't need to build their own softwar...
items.content: No, I don't think that AI will destroy *all* SaaS. Most people don't need to build their own software, just like most people never ended up building their own website. But there is a HUGE chunk of SaaS corporations that have been almost exclusively extracting value without providing any meaningful benefits for decades, and I honestly, sincerely, deeply hope that AI takes all of them out.

items.title: In a way I prefer the American AI companies because they're mostly public (Google etc) or will be pu...
items.content:
In a way I prefer the American AI companies because they're mostly public (Google etc) or will be public at some point by IPO (OpenAI, Anthropic) so the people can actually participate and profit from automating them out of their jobs

The Chinese models and companies are great and top the benchmarks but either they stay private forever or they go public on Chinese stock markets which don't really work like the ones in the US (it's more smoke and mirrors there) so you can't benefit from them so much as a stock holder

Having only private companies own the models that you can't invest in would be the true dystopia you don't want

American public stock markets where literally anyone can buy a stock in any public company are really the one of the most socially friendly and in a way communist (in a good way) things invented we should be grateful for existing

items.title:
To be very, very clear: I didn‚Äôt write this to scare people.

I just think it‚Äôs our duty (those of u...
items.content:
To be very, very clear: I didn‚Äôt write this to scare people.

I just think it‚Äôs our duty (those of us in the AI space) to share what we‚Äôre seeing so people at least have a sense of what may be happening.

Even if there‚Äôs a small chance things play out like I, and many others, expect, people have the right to know in advance so they can at least spend a little time thinking about it and preparing.

This has gone way more viral than I ever possibly imagined‚Ä¶ and the reaction to it is much more extreme than I expected.

It‚Äôs very possible we will be entering a very weird, new world in the coming years (or we may not!) and I think it‚Äôs important that people spend at least a little time thinking about what this might mean for them, and how they should prepare.

If nothing else, I‚Äôm glad this article got people talking about this stuff.

items.summary: Matt Shumer reflecting on viral reception of his article about AI's transformative/disruptive potential, emphasizing duty to share observations and help people prepare.

I just think it‚Äôs our duty (those of us in the AI space) to share what we‚Äôre seeing so people at least have a sense of what may be happening.

Even if there‚Äôs a small chance things play out like I, and many others, expect, people have the right to know in advance so they can at least spend a little time thinking about it and preparing.

This has gone way more viral than I ever possibly imagined‚Ä¶ and the reaction to it is much more extreme than I expected.

It‚Äôs very possible we will be entering a very weird, new world in the coming years (or we may not!) and I think it‚Äôs important that people spend at least a little time thinking about what this might mean for them, and how they should prepare.

If nothing else, I‚Äôm glad this article got people talking about this stuff.

items.title:
I went from writing code to writing specs.

That's most of what I'm doing now.

From writing loops a...
items.content:
I went from writing code to writing specs.

That's most of what I'm doing now.

From writing loops and conditions to describing what I want to build.

Basically, I'm now operating at a much higher level of abstraction. Much more focus on the WHAT to build, instead of the HOW to build it.

I still write a lot of code, mostly things that I don't know how to describe properly, or the model can't get quite right.

I also spend a ton of time reviewing code. Way more than ever before.

A lot has changed for me over the last year or so.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago (svpino) describing his shift from writing code to writing specs, operating at higher abstraction levels while spending more time reviewing AI-generated code.
items.reasoning: High engagement (255 likes, 17.6K views) first-person account of how AI coding tools are transforming a senior engineer's daily work. Concrete, relatable description of the new developer workflow.
items.summary_html: Santiago (svpino) describing his shift from writing code to writing specs, operating at higher abstraction levels while spending more time reviewing AI-generated code.
items.content_html:
I went from writing code to writing specs.

That's most of what I'm doing now.

From writing loops and conditions to describing what I want to build.

Basically, I'm now operating at a much higher level of abstraction. Much more focus on the WHAT to build, instead of the HOW to build it.

I still write a lot of code, mostly things that I don't know how to describe properly, or the model can't get quite right.

I also spend a ton of time reviewing code. Way more than ever before.

A lot has changed for me over the last year or so.

items.title: My biggest fear is that the AI will become *too good* in certain very valuable and very scalable sub...
items.content: My biggest fear is that the AI will become *too good* in certain very valuable and very scalable subdomains, that we'll all be forced to reorient ALL of human work around those use cases, instead of trying to adopt AI for the workflows that we are used to and come more naturally.

items.summary: Tunguz expresses concern that AI becoming too good in specific scalable subdomains could force all human work to reorient around those use cases rather than adapting AI to natural workflows.

items.title:
I've been running 4-6 coding agents every single day for months now:

I have 2 - 3 instances of Clau...
items.content:
I've been running 4-6 coding agents every single day for months now:

I have 2 - 3 instances of Claude Code.
I have Copilot.
I have Warp.
I have Jules.

I'm figuring this out as I go, but it's getting really hard to keep track of everything that's happening.

90% of the time, I can't remember which agent is working on what. I can't keep context in my head, and I forget to check the agent that finished 30 minutes ago.

Models aren't the bottleneck anymore.

I am.

I think there's one solution for this:
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Valdarrama describes running 4-6 coding agents daily and struggling to track them all. Says 'I am the bottleneck, not the models' - signaling need for agent orchestration.
items.reasoning: Authentic developer experience report about the multi-agent workflow challenge. The observation that the human is now the bottleneck, not the models, is an important signal about where AI development is heading.

items.content:
Extracting complex patent documents üí°üìÑ with natural language

Patent documents are long and have varied sections: claims, prior art references, figures, and more. Our agent builder lets you express what you want to extract through natural language, and builds a workflow that lets you extract 1M+ patent documents accurately at scale!

Check out the video below. Define the overall extraction in the chat builder, which deploys an agent app that can extract over any document and flag uncertain fields.

If you have complex documents that you want to analyze, come check out our agent builder in LlamaCloud. You don‚Äôt even have to write a single line of code!

https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8

items.title:
@warpdotdev released Oz, and it might be the missing piece we all need:

Oz is a cloud-based coding ...
items.content:
@warpdotdev released Oz, and it might be the missing piece we all need:

Oz is a cloud-based coding agent with built-in orchestration (the *cloud* part is important because you don't have to run it locally).

You set up isolated environments, point them at your repos, and manage everything from a single panel.

You can see everything running in a single place (instead of having to tab-switch between terminals):

‚Ä¢ Local agents
‚Ä¢ Cloud agents
‚Ä¢ Scheduled agents
‚Ä¢ Agents triggered from the API (Slack, GitHub Actions, etc.)

You can control every agent from that dashboard.

You can even fork cloud agents to run on your local computer!

Agents are the future. We aren't going to run one or two agents; we'll run many of them.

Now, the question is how in the world we are going to manage all of these agents.

Oz is going to be huge.

Check it out here and get 1000 free credits when you sign up for a plan at https://t.co/t1Ua7AK5f2

Thanks to the Warp team for partnering with me on this post.

items.title:
‚ÄúThe hard part is deciding what deserves to exist, and why.‚Äù

Creative director is the job of the fu...
items.content:
‚ÄúThe hard part is deciding what deserves to exist, and why.‚Äù

Creative director is the job of the future.

Eventually the dopamine wears off.

Then what?

Those who can redefine meaning for humans will have relevance.

Like racing autonomous robots in Abu Dhabi. 

8,000 people showed up. And loved it. Everyone else hated it. Deeply. But every year more of them will see robots as more fun. The whole goal is to go faster. And AI does.

We are all competing for your attention.

Real artists can do it.

I suck at it. But am taking notes.

Which I feed to an AI to improve it.

‚ÄúOh, dad, it isn‚Äôt entertaining if it doesn‚Äôt have sex or violence,‚Äù my now 31-year-old son once told me.‚Äù

The art is in proving him wrong.

items.title: Most neural networks see the input data as a matrix or a vector, like pixels in rows and columns or ...
items.content:
Most neural networks see the input data as a matrix or a vector, like pixels in rows and columns or words in a sequence.

A lot of real-world data is better described as a graph: a set of nodes connected by edges, like social networks, power grids, or molecules.

Graph neural networks try to process this kind of data, and the most common approach before this paper (GCNs) treated every neighbor of a node as equally important when aggregating information. This ICLR 2018 paper, published by Bengio's team and since then garnered more than 18,000 citations, introduces Graph Attention Networks (GATs), which borrow the idea of attention in language models to let each node learn which of its neighbors matter more for a given task.

The attention weights are computed using a small shared neural network that looks at pairs of connected nodes, so the model doesn't need to know the full graph structure ahead of time and can generalize to entirely new graphs it's never seen during training.

It's an exemplary AI research paper. The architecture is simple enough to describe in a few equations, runs efficiently in parallel, and at the time matched or beat everything else on standard benchmarks.

Read online with an AI tutor: https://t.co/nhM2JTFQEi
Read offline on your own: https://t.co/yk8MCjgECS
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov provides an educational overview of Graph Attention Networks (GATs), an ICLR 2018 paper with 18K+ citations from Bengio's team.
items.reasoning: Good educational content about a foundational paper with decent engagement (406 likes). Valuable for ML education but not news.

‚Ä¢ The stepwise automation framework: start in controlled depot environments, then move to shunting yards, and only later to mainline operations.

‚Ä¢ Why data sovereignty and interoperable standards are the real keys to convincing stakeholders to collaborate.

‚Ä¢ How AI is reshaping rail jobs‚Äînot eliminating them, but modernizing them into more attractive, data-driven roles.

items.title: Funny that I just posted the other day about training a binary-to-source-code model, but Elon wants ...
items.content:
Funny that I just posted the other day about training a binary-to-source-code model, but Elon wants to bypass the source code part entirely.

I'm not sure how well a language model would generate binary. Understanding it can be done using a visual model, but image generation models aren't as good at generating as vision models are at recognizing.

items.content_html:

Understanding the costs, benefits, and tradeoffs of various models, companies, etc quickly becomes job #1 if you are building anything substantial.

It's one thing I'm trying to automate "hey Grok please analyze all the models for me and tell me how I can do xxxxxxxxx cheaper."

A new issue of my weekly AI newsletter is out. In this issue:

[HBR] AI doesn‚Äôt reduce work‚Äîit intensifies it

[Google] Towards a science of scaling agent systems: When and why agent systems work

The post-Transformer era: State space models, Mamba, and what comes after attention

[Explained] Visualized speculative decoding

[MIT] Helping AI agents search to get the best results out of large language models

[Tool] torchvista: Interactive Pytorch forward pass visualization in notebooks

[Model] Qwen3-Coder-Next: Pushing small hybrid models on agentic coding

[ArXiv] PaperBanana: Automating academic illustration for AI scientists

https://t.co/rLh46Q8vZb

@gm_mertd and that's *not* about competing with frontier models, but using their advantage to build some specific intelligence *to them*

using another different analogy that we all get, they migrate from heroku because it didn't scale with them. They don't need to be AWS but they def need to know how to manage their own infra (datacenter, cloud, k8s, dbs etc) specific to them. That is just part of the job

items.title: I thought about posting a similar disclaimer for my tweets, mostly because it would be 99.99% true a...
items.content: I thought about posting a similar disclaimer for my tweets, mostly because it would be 99.99% true as well. I tweet primarily because I have fun doing it as a human activity. But I also share memes that come my way, and have created a (very) few posts with AI. In general I don‚Äôt want to constrain myself in any way. My attitude to tweeting has always been to post whatever the heck I feel like. If you have an issue with that, I won‚Äôt judge you, your taste is your taste, feel free to ignore me.

items.title:
@j_bertho May I be so bold as to challenge you to switch for a week?

Unless you‚Äôre a professional s...
items.content:
@j_bertho May I be so bold as to challenge you to switch for a week?

Unless you‚Äôre a professional stenographer or have a condition that hampers your speech or are typing non natural language (eg code, math), speaking is still faster. Average wpm for english speakers is 150 says the googs. 

And it‚Äôs not just that it‚Äôs faster, it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs more natural. (And I still use keyboard shortcuts and copy/paste/screenshot/window swap with my keyboard.)

I‚Äôm not paid by the non-existent voice lobby to convince anyone of this but I am largely convinced that most people just haven‚Äôt tried it yet. 

Watch this to compare 100v150v200 wpm. The 150 actually seems on the slow side: https://t.co/SGLpFoYHfp
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Allie K Miller makes an enthusiastic case for voice input over typing, citing 150 WPM speaking speed vs typical typing speeds and challenging someone to try it for a week.
items.reasoning: Interesting perspective on voice-first computing workflows from a notable AI figure. Moderate engagement (1138 views). Tangentially relevant to AI voice interfaces.
items.summary_html: Allie K Miller makes an enthusiastic case for voice input over typing, citing 150 WPM speaking speed vs typical typing speeds and challenging someone to try it for a week.
items.content_html:
@j_bertho May I be so bold as to challenge you to switch for a week?

Unless you‚Äôre a professional stenographer or have a condition that hampers your speech or are typing non natural language (eg code, math), speaking is still faster. Average wpm for english speakers is 150 says the googs.

And it‚Äôs not just that it‚Äôs faster, it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs more natural. (And I still use keyboard shortcuts and copy/paste/screenshot/window swap with my keyboard.)

I‚Äôm not paid by the non-existent voice lobby to convince anyone of this but I am largely convinced that most people just haven‚Äôt tried it yet.

Watch this to compare 100v150v200 wpm. The 150 actually seems on the slow side: https://t.co/SGLpFoYHfp

And hope to minimize those who would use it to bring deep harm.

One random hack for the more traditional uses and not coding (you‚Äôre going to say it sounds like overkill) is that I sometimes use 2 mics - Bose and wired apple. He experiments a lot, tries different things, sees what grows, he seems to know what he's doing

I managed Nomad List's community and that was 10,000 people at any point and the amount of shit I got for trying to improve things

Now imagine that with 200 million users

I think he does well

items.summary_html: levelsio defends Elon Musk's management of X/Twitter, praising his experimentation approach.
items.content_html:
@marcospereeira Even if I wasn't on X I think he's great

He experiments a lot, tries different things, sees what grows, he seems to know what he's doing

I managed Nomad List's community and that was 10,000 people at any point and the amount of shit I got for trying to improve things

You do something to improve for group A and now group B gets angry

Now imagine that with 200 million users

I think he does well

items.title: Over 50 millions views for that @MattShumer_ blog (‚ÄúSomething Big is Happening‚Äù) and not a shred of ...
items.content:
Over 50 millions views for that @MattShumer_ blog (‚ÄúSomething Big is Happening‚Äù) and not a shred of actual data. Nobody thought to ask what are the data? Does this match reality? Is Shumer credible? Did he give a single concrete example? 

People gonna believe what they want to believe, here are 8 or 9 critical points most people missed:

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer‚Äôs blog post is weaponized hype, filled with vivid narrative and marketing speech, but stumbles on the facts, especially with respect to reliability. He gives no actual data to support this claim that the latest coding systems can write whole complex apps without making errors.  

‚Ä¢¬†When he describes how AI‚Äôs are doing longer and longer tasks on METR‚Äôs famous task-time benchmark, he neglects to say the criterion on that benchmark is 50% correct, not 100%, and that the benchmark is only about coding and not tasks in general. No AI system can reliably do every five-hour long task humans can do without error, or even close. But you wouldn‚Äôt know that reading Shumer‚Äôs blog, which largely ignores all the hallucination and boneheaded errors that are so common in every day experience. 

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer didn‚Äôt cite the new Caltech/Stanford article that reviews a wide range of reasoning errors in so-called reasoning models [or the Apple reasoning paper or the ASU mirage paper, etc]. The picture he sells just isn‚Äôt realistic, however much people might wish it were true. 

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer is the guy who was once famous for apparently exaggerated claims about a big model of his that didn‚Äôt replicate and that many people saw as fraud; he likes to sell big. But that doesn‚Äôt mean we should take him seriously.

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer made no reference to a different METR study showed that coders sometimes imagine big productivity gains where they actually lost productivity. (Even though he selectively mentioned their other well-known study).

‚Ä¢ He also didn‚Äôt acknowledge that other user‚Äôs experience is certainly not ‚Äúit‚Äôs usually perfect.‚Äù @KelseyTuocreported a few weeks back that Claude Code was sometimes perfect, and other times maddening. (Example: ‚ÄúSometimes, Claude is absolutely the worst coworker you‚Äôve ever had. At one point, it deleted every single one of the phoneme files of each English sound pronounced [that she was working with in her app] absolutely correctly, which I had personally emailed an English teacher to secure permission to use, and replaced them with AI-generated sounds which were all subtly wrong.‚Äù) Shumer glosses over that kind of experience. ‚Ä®Ôøº
‚Ä¢LLMs write code wicked fast, but some coders are starting to report burnout, and only relatively modest gains relative to that burnout, as a new story from Connie Loizos at Tech Crunch just reported.

‚Ä¢¬†Shumer is actually correct that something has changed recently. You really can let things rip more in the most recent systems. Bit, quoting from a developer friend ‚Äúsometimes!  [it] will come out with the right answer. ‚Ä¶ Sometimes‚Ä¶ [But] ultimately, I think this makes it more dangerous ‚Ä¶. Generally, the closer these systems are to appearing right, the more dangerous they become‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚Ä¢ The security of the autogenerated code is very much in question. 

The bottom line is this: LLMs are certainly coding more, but it‚Äôs not clear that the code they are creating is secure or trustworthy. Shumer‚Äôs presentation is completely one-sided, omitting lots of concerns that have been widely expressed here and elsewhere. 

A lot of people may have taken his post seriously, but they shouldn‚Äôt have.

Adapted from my newsletter, Marcus on AI (nearly 100k subscribers).

(Example: ‚ÄúSometimes, Claude is absolutely the worst coworker you‚Äôve ever had. At one point, it deleted every single one of the phoneme files of each English sound pronounced [that she was working with in her app] absolutely correctly, which I had personally emailed an English teacher to secure permission to use, and replaced them with AI-generated sounds which were all subtly wrong.‚Äù) Shumer glosses over that kind of experience. ‚Ä®Ôøº

[it] will come out with the right answer. ‚Ä¶ Sometimes‚Ä¶ [But] ultimately, I think this makes it more dangerous ‚Ä¶. Generally, the closer these systems are to appearing right, the more dangerous they become‚Ä¶‚Äù

items.title:
When was the last time you read a good post-mortem?

I consulted for a company that famously joked a...
items.content:
When was the last time you read a good post-mortem?

I consulted for a company that famously joked about storing passwords in post-mortems because they knew no one would ever read them.

This is the circle of life:

Issue ‚Üí Fix ‚Üí Post-mortem ‚Üí Nobody reads it ‚Üí Same issue happens again a week later.

Let's be honest:

99% of companies treat post-mortems as a compliance exercise.

Meanwhile, they are missing a huge opportunity to teach employees.

The difference between a useless post-mortem and a good one is STRUCTURE.

items.content:
@scispace 6/
(3) Mendeley Integration ‚Äî Users can connect their Mendeley account to the @SciSpace Agent. As with Zotero, this integration fills the gap between reference management and research work (literature discovery, paper analysis, writing, citations, and reporting) in one research workflow platform.

This includes:
‚óè Access to all Mendeley PDFs instantly.
‚óè Import files directly into the Agent workflow.
‚óè Detect and track new added files and also obsolete removed files automatically

items.content:
@scispace 5/
(2) Seamless Zotero Integration for Easy Reference and Citation Management ‚Äî Zotero users now easily become @SciSpace users, with all of this functionality built-in:
‚óè Import Zotero libraries into SciSpace.
‚óè Ask questions to Zotero-stored papers.
‚óè Generate cited content using Zotero references.

items.content_html:
@mikekock So NL, DE, DK and SE are the strictest IRS in Europe I think

What happens is they want you to really move permanently out of the country, unregister yourself from your municipality and essentially never come back

Then you REALLY need to register in a new place where you ACTUALLY live physically or they can still backtax you

items.title:
Dutch people being angry when their world famous top athlete is flying private

Says a lot about the...
items.content:
Dutch people being angry when their world famous top athlete is flying private

Says a lot about the degrowth mentality that infected the majority of the country (and Western Europe)

Reward excellence! Or there'll be no incentive to be excellent anymore and nobody will try to be in the first place

Which is exactly how you end up with a dying culture

items.summary: Levelsio commentary on Dutch cultural attitudes toward success and private jets.
